thread.title: Macy’s Has a Spring in its Step

author: Elizabeth Winkler
title: Macy’s Has a Spring in its Step
text:
0 COMMENTS After quarters upon quarters of declining sales, Macy’s M 4.59% may be turning a corner. For the first time in three years it reported positive sales growth .
Shares jumped 4.5% Tuesday morning. In a call with analysts, Chief Executive Jeffrey Gennette declared that the company’s leadership has found a “clear path to return Macy’s to growth.”
Adjusted earnings per share for the fourth quarter came in at $2.82, beating estimates of $2.71, and revenue reached $8.67 billion, an increase of 1.8% over the same period last year. For fiscal year 2017, earnings were $5.04 a share, compared with $1.99 a share a year ago.
Much of the company’s success is due to an unusually strong holiday season and consumer optimism. It also acknowledged the benefits of U.S. tax cuts, which boosted earnings by 7 cents a share. 
And the company is learning from past mistakes—for instance, by maintaining a healthy inventory so it doesn’t need additional discounts and can respond swiftly to trends. There is a lot of talk of “testing” and “iterating” with initiatives such as its new loyalty program .
That emphasis on aggressive experimentation is smart in a challenged industry. Yet Macy’s is still very much in transition. Its guidance for 2018 is optimistic, promising earnings of between $3.55 and $3.75 a share. But it is worth keeping in mind that the industry is suffused with optimism at the moment.
“If they had to give full-year guidance three months ago or six months from now, it would look different,” says Simeon Siegel of Nomura Securities. “But right now you’re coming on the heels of a strong holiday season and tax savings.”
None of retail’s structural challenges have disappeared. Macy’s, which had seemed to be among the industry’s losers, suddenly looks as if it stands a chance of making it out among the winners. As Mr. Gennette acknowledged, though, “We still have a lot to do and a lot to improve.”
